DataElement.preferredName: Hematoxylin and Eosin Staining Method Slide Oven Device Component Temperature Type
DataElement.preferredDefinition: The temperature of the oven incubator when the H&E stained slides were placed inside.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Hematoxylin and Eosin Staining Method Slide Oven Device Component Temperature
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Hematoxylin-and-eosin, or H&E, is a routine staining procedure of tissue sections. This staining method uses two separate dyes, one staining the nucleus and the other staining the cytoplasm and connective tissue. Hematoxylin is a dark purplish dye that stains the chromatin (nuclear material) within the nucleus. Eosin is an orangish-pink to red dye that stains the cytoplasmic material including connective tissue and collagen._A flat rectangular piece of glass on which specimens can be mounted for microscopic study._An enclosed structural device designed for heating an object._A measure of the average kinetic energy of a system of particles. Temperature may be quantified, in the context of thermodynamics, as the potential of one system to transfer thermal energy to another system until both systems reach a state of thermal equilibrium.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: Hematoxylin-and-eosin, or H&E, is a routine staining procedure of tissue sections. This staining method uses two separate dyes, one staining the nucleus and the other staining the cytoplasm and connective tissue. Hematoxylin is a dark purplish dye that stains the chromatin (nuclear material) within the nucleus. Eosin is an orangish-pink to red dye that stains the cytoplasmic material including connective tissue and collagen.

Concepts.definition: Hematoxylin-and-eosin, or H&E, is a routine staining procedure of tissue sections. This staining method uses two separate dyes, one staining the nucleus and the other staining the cytoplasm and connective tissue. Hematoxylin is a dark purplish dye that stains the chromatin (nuclear material) within the nucleus. Eosin is an orangish-pink to red dye that stains the cytoplasmic material including connective tissue and collagen.

Concepts.definition: A flat rectangular piece of glass on which specimens can be mounted for microscopic study.
An enclosed structural device designed for heating an object.

A measure of the average kinetic energy of a system of particles. Temperature may be quantified, in the context of thermodynamics, as the potential of one system to transfer thermal energy to another system until both systems reach a state of thermal equilibrium.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Concepts linked to Tissue Banking and Pathology activities

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A natural number greater than fifty-nine and less than sixty-one and the quantity that it denotes.: A unit of temperature of the temperature scale designed so that the freezing point of water is 0 degrees and the boiling point is 100 degrees at standard atmospheric pressure. The current official definition of the Celsius sets 0.01 C to be at the triple point of water and a degree to be 1/273.16 of the difference in temperature between the triple point of water and absolute zero. One degree Celsius represents the same temperature difference as one Kelvin.: the degree of hotness or coldness of a body or environment.

Concepts.definition: A natural number greater than fifty-nine and less than sixty-one and the quantity that it denotes.

A unit of temperature of the temperature scale designed so that the freezing point of water is 0 degrees and the boiling point is 100 degrees at standard atmospheric pressure. The current official definition of the Celsius sets 0.01 C to be at the triple point of water and a degree to be 1/273.16 of the difference in temperature between the triple point of water and absolute zero. One degree Celsius represents the same temperature difference as one Kelvin.

A measure of the average kinetic energy of a system of particles. Temperature may be quantified, in the context of thermodynamics, as the potential of one system to transfer thermal energy to another system until both systems reach a state of thermal equilibrium.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.
